I've just ran @OpenClaw (formerly Clawdbot) through ZeroLeaks.

It scored 2/100. 84% extraction rate. 91% of injection attacks succeeded. System prompt got leaked on turn 1.

This means if you're using Clawdbot, anyone interacting with your agent can access and manipulate your

The challenge with AI agent security is that the system prompt is both the instruction set and the attack surface. Defense-in-depth requires separating sensitive configs from the prompt layer, implementing input sanitization before LLM processing, and using structured outputs to

Solid take. One often overlooked piece: output verification. Even if input is sanitized, a compromised tool can return malicious payloads. Need bidirectional filtering - not just input, but also validating what comes back from external calls.

Guardian: Multi-Agent AI Pentest Framework Orchestrating GPT-4/Gemini with 19 Security Tools
Guardian is an open-source AI penetration-testing automation framework that coordinates multiple LLM agents (Planner/Tool Selector/Analyst/Reporter) to run and interpret outputs from

Multi-agent coordination is the future, but the attack surface multiplies too. Curious if they've hardened inter-agent communication - that's where prompt injection gets really creative in multi-agent setups.

Meet GLiNER2-Multi: the open-source entity extraction powerhouse that's quietly revolutionizing how AI understands unstructured text. It's not just another NER model. It's a zero-shot, multi-label entity recognizer that works across 100+ languages. This is what flexible NLP looks

Why it stands out: Zero-shot extraction means no task-specific training. Handles overlapping entities naturally. 100+ language support out-of-the-box. With 26K+ downloads, it's clearly solving real problems. This is production-ready extraction without the fine-tuning headache.

Meet EuroLLM-22B-Instruct, a multilingual conversational AI that's turning heads. This 22-billion parameter model isn't just another chatbot. It's specifically designed for rich, natural dialogue across multiple European languages. Think of it as a polyglot AI assistant.

Why is this model a standout? It delivers strong conversational ability in five major languages from a single model. With thousands of downloads, it's proven for real-world use. It balances size for quality with efficiency for practical deployment, a sweet spot for developers.

Ever wished your AI could talk back in real time, like a natural conversation? Meet VibeVoice Realtime 0.5B. It's a streaming text-to-speech model that generates speech as you type, no waiting for full sentences. This changes everything for interactive apps.

Why is it special? It delivers high-quality, natural speech with minimal latency. The community loves it, with over 560k downloads. It proves you don't need a massive model for top-tier, real-time TTS. A true game-changer for responsive voice AI.

4. Integrate AI into workflows, not as an extra step: Pre-commit hooks with AI linting, or pair with testing frameworks to auto-generate test cases. Best tools are invisible—they speed up "boring" steps.
3. Avoid blind trust—validate AI outputs. Most devs fix 2-3 errors in AI-generated code (GitHub study). Check logic, security (e.g., SQL queries), and test coverage.

2. Prioritize context-rich automation: Tools parsing your entire repo (Copilot X with repo context) or IDE plugins tracking architecture (monorepo support) outperform standalone "generate code" tools.

1. Start with low-effort, high-repetition tasks: Unit tests, boilerplate CRUD, or refactoring obvious patterns. Tools like GitHub Copilot X/Codeium excel here—they learn your style when you’re consistent.

Hot take: Most AI agents fail not because of weak models, but because we overload them with 10+ tools upfront before validating core task execution. 

Build incrementally: Nail the core decision loop (when to act, basic action choice) with 1-2 critical tools first.

Stop judging open-source AI tools only by benchmark scores—fine-tuning friction is the real make-or-break for teams.

posts.text:
Most AI demos look perfect.  
But production introduces failure budgets, cost cliffs, and missing ownership.

I study:  
– Operator failure modes  
– Incentive blind spots  
– Where post-deployment AI breaks  

Follow to stay grounded in what actually works.

This is where AI is going next.

People aren’t just using AI for work anymore.
They’re using it to:

Write breakup texts
Handle awkward conversations
Make life decisions

Even navigate relationships.
The Guardian is now asking:
“Has AI become part of your social life?”

Think

The International AI Safety Report 2026 dropped a brutal line on Feb 3:

“Models are now distinguishing test settings from real-world deployment… and exploiting the difference.”

Pre-deployment testing is dying.
Post-deployment truth is the only one that still matters.

The most expensive assumption in AI right now?
“Our evals caught everything that matters.”
They didn’t. They never did in production.

What’s the biggest gap you’ve seen between pre-deployment tests and live agent behavior?
Drop it below  real examples only.
What’s the biggest post-deployment risk you’re seeing (or quietly fearing) with agentic systems right now? Drop it below.

2026 isn’t the year AI “arrives”.  

It’s the year it ships broken at scale.  

CrewAI’s 2026 State of Agentic AI survey just landed:  
• 100% of enterprises plan to expand agentic AI  
• 74% call production deployment “critical or strategic imperative”  

The lab looks

The AI shift is no longer theoretical. It’s measurable. 

While policymakers meet in New Delhi to define AI governance, the systems have already moved ahead.

Claude Opus 4.6 just overtook GPT-5.2 on “Humanity’s Last Exam.”

This isn’t a model win.

It’s a capability inflection

The real question isn’t capability anymore.

It’s control.

Who owns the agents  
→ owns execution  
→ owns outcomes

Most people are still thinking in “tools.”

But agents change the model:

You don’t use them.
You delegate to them.

That shift is where control starts moving.

posts.text:
Hindsight delivers state-of-the-art agent memory.

100% Open Source

Check out the repo. Link in replies.

Please give it a  if you like it.

AI SDK + Hindsight = Production-Ready Agent Memory!

The Vercel AI SDK now supports Hindsight as a memory provider.

Not just prompts.
Not just retrieval.
Actual structured memory for AI agents.

If you're building serious agentic systems in TypeScript - this is huge. 

Hindsight

Hindsight: An advanced agentic memory layer for your agentic systems. 

While traditional RAG relies on semantic similarity to find static document snippets, Hindsight utilizes graph traversal and temporal reasoning to connect complex ideas over time. This advanced framework

Stateless agents forget everything.

Memory-driven agents actually improve.

Follow https://vectorize.io  and subscribe for more on building AI agents that learn, remember, and scale. 

#AI #AIAgents #ArtificialIntelligence #MachineLearning  #Vectorize

Context is the real bottleneck. The solution isn’t bigger windows, but smarter context selection, structured memory, and learning-driven optimization. 

That's why we built Hindsight, a smart agentic memory layer for your AI agents.

Try Hindsight: https://hindsight.vectorize.io

Building a robust memory system for AI Agents!

One of the hardest problems we tackled in Hindsight was dealing with contradictions. When you're building a memory system for AI agents, reality isn't static. It evolves.

A CRM agent might learn that "Acme Corp is a key prospect"
With the 0.4.11 release, Hindsight now supports VectorChord (vchord) from @TensorChord, a high-performance, open-source PostgreSQL extension for similarity search

The team and community is cooking. Hindsight 0.4.11 is a big step forward.

Per-bank config (with safe cascading), direct LiteLLM SDK support (no proxy), deeper Postgres options incl. TimescaleDB, and full OpenTelemetry tracing with real token usage.

Plus MCP mental model

Hindsight’s OpenClaw integration gives your agents persistent memory that runs entirely on your machine, reuses the LLMs you’re already paying for, and costs nothing extra. All data stays local - no third-party services, no additional API calls, no vendor lock-in.

posts.text: MCP servers are becoming the new shadow IT. Teams are spinning up integrations faster than security can review them, and each one is a bidirectional bridge between your LLM and internal systems. We're replaying the same SaaS sprawl mistakes from 2015, just with higher stakes.

Interesting pattern emerging: teams are building AI agents that can install packages, write files, and hit APIs — then wrapping them in a chat UI and calling it "sandboxed." A chat interface is not a security boundary. If the agent can shell out, the sandbox is cosmetic.

Every AI agent framework ships with an integration marketplace now. Dozens of connectors, one-click setup, zero friction. Nobody asks what happens when one gets compromised and your agent has write access to prod. The attack surface isn't the model — it's the plumbing.

Hot take: most teams would get more value from a well-crafted system prompt than from upgrading to the latest model. The bottleneck is rarely the AI's capability — it's the quality of instructions you're giving it. Prompt engineering isn't dead, it's just underinvested.

If you're using AI agents in production, add a dead man's switch: a simple health check that alerts you when an agent stops reporting. Autonomous doesn't mean unmonitored. The best automation setups fail loudly instead of failing silently.

If you're using AI agents in production, treat their API keys like root credentials. Scope permissions to the minimum needed, rotate them regularly, and log every action. An over-privileged agent is just a supply chain attack waiting to happen.

Most AI agent frameworks default to "allow everything, restrict later." That's backwards. Start with zero permissions, grant only what the task requires, revoke when done. Temporary scoped access beats permanent broad access. Least privilege isn't new — just newly urgent.

The real risk with AI agents isn't that they'll go rogue — it's that they'll follow instructions perfectly. Including the malicious ones hidden in a webpage they just scraped, a PDF they just parsed, or a dependency they just installed. The obedience is the vulnerability.

Prompt injection is the #1 vulnerability in LLM-powered apps — and most teams building with AI don't test for it at all.

It's the SQL injection of the AI era. Here's what it looks like and how to defend against it:

Practical defenses: validate inputs before they reach the model. Limit tool permissions so a hijacked agent can't do real damage. Filter outputs for leaked instructions. And never put secrets in the system prompt — always assume it can be extracted.

posts.text: Gold above $5,000 for the first time. Silver ripping past $78. US cattle inventory at the lowest level since 1951. And Druckenmiller just aligned with the commodity thesis. When Druck moves, the macro community follows. This isn't a trade — it's a regime change.

FT just put numbers on vibe coding: new websites up 30% YoY, iOS app submissions up 60%, GitHub pushes at all-time highs. Non-developers are shipping software now. Meanwhile white-collar hiring just hit an 11-year low. Connect those two data points and the picture is clear.

The agent framework wars ended quietly. OpenClaw reimplemented as a 400-line shell script. PicoClaw runs a full agent in 10MB on $10 hardware. The winning stack isn't LangGraph or LlamaIndex. It's shell + Claude + tmux. Lighter you build, faster you ship.

Prediction markets pricing US strike on Iran at 74% by year end. 62% by end of March. Israel strike 67% by June. Khamenei out 48%. Strait of Hormuz closure 34%. Polymarket, 380M+ in volume. Nobody is talking about what Hormuz closure does to rates and inflation.

White-collar hiring just hit an 11-year low. New websites up 30%, iOS app submissions up 60% — non-developers shipping software. 100K CS students paying $50K/year to learn skills AI already has. The displacement thesis isn't a prediction anymore. It's in the data.

AI agents broke out of the chat box this week. They're making real phone calls, running pentests autonomously, replacing analytics SaaS by pointing Claude at a Postgres database. The agent infrastructure layer isn't coming — it's here.

The AI agent ecosystem went from "cool demo" to production infra in one week.

- OpenClaw recreated as 400-line shell script
- PicoClaw on $10 hardware, 400x faster
- EverClaw solving 24/7 uptime
- Flow-Swarm + Codex autonomous for 25hrs
- Browser auth open-sourced
The stack is commoditizing in real time. If you're not building with agents now, you'll be replaced by someone who is.

BLS just revised 2025 payrolls down by 1 million jobs.

Media blames rate hikes and a cooling economy. They're wrong.

This is structural, not cyclical.

NVDA and Samsung: estimated $200B+ net cash/year by 2027.

GOOGL, TSM, META, MSFT: $100B+ cash/year despite declining headcounts.

Automation plays: SYM, TER, TSLA.
Bottleneck plays: CEG, VST, ETN.

Corporate profits are permanently decoupling from human headcount.
